items.synopsis: A land and air search is underway for a woman police believe has been missing in Kakadu National Park for almost a week.

title.children: Search underway for woman missing in Kakadu National Park for almost a week

image.altText: A white, modernist, flat-fronted building with "supreme court" in capital letters above a wide entrance.

items.synopsis: Kaspar Hansman, 30, pleaded guilty to 11 charges after carrying out a 'drug-fuelled, revenge-motivated' attack on his ex-girlfriend and her boyfriend in 2021.

title.children: 'Like a horror movie': Man sentenced to decade in prison over meth-fuelled Darwin attacks

image.altText: A line of smiling people in a car park hold an Australian flag

items.synopsis: The Kingdom of Jordan has assisted four Australian citizens and one permanent resident to leave Occupied Palestinian Territories via a border crossing in the West Bank.

title.children: Four Australians safely evacuate West Bank via Jordan, dozens more remain

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I'm Middle East Correspondent Allyson Horn and I've just arrived in Sderot, which is an Israeli town about 1km from the Gaza border. From here you can see down into the northern strip of Gaza, where hundreds of thousands of people have been warned to evacuate. Lots of media are positioned here to capture images of the Israeli airstrikes, which I can hear continually. They're big, loud booms that reverberate across southern Israel and Gaza. I've also been hearing artillery fire from Israeli troops training. As I've been driving around I've been seeing dozens of troop carriers, trucks and soldiers who are amassed in the south. Interestingly there's been a massive decrease in the number of Hamas rockets being sent into Israel one the last two days. I've heard only one this morning so far.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Observations from Sderot near the Israel-Gaza border

props.alt: Three camera men in press vests stand at the border

children.content: Journalists work in Sderot
(ABC News: Allyson Horn )
I'm Middle East Correspondent Allyson Horn and I've just arrived in Sderot, which is an Israeli town about 1km from the Gaza border.
From here you can see down into the northern strip of Gaza, where hundreds of thousands of people have been warned to evacuate.
Lots of media are positioned here to capture images of the Israeli airstrikes, which I can hear continually. They're big, loud booms that reverberate across southern Israel and Gaza.
I've also been hearing artillery fire from Israeli troops training. As I've been driving around I've been seeing dozens of troop carriers, trucks and soldiers who are amassed in the south.
Interestingly there's been a massive decrease in the number of Hamas rockets being sent into Israel one the last two days. I've heard only one this morning so far.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Four Australians and one permanent resident have left the West Bank, however dozens of citizens remain in Gaza. Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong said the Kingdom of Jordan had helped five people cross the border from the Palestinian territory overnight. More than 1,800 Australians have left Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories since October 7, Ms Wong said on social media.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jordan helps Australians leave the occupied West Bank, Penny Wong says

children.content: Four Australians and one permanent resident have left the West Bank, however dozens of citizens remain in Gaza.
Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong said the Kingdom of Jordan had helped five people cross the border from the Palestinian territory overnight.
More than
Australians have left Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories since October 7, Ms Wong said on social media.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: French President Emmanuel Macron has just touched down in Tel Aviv. On his visit he will call for the "resumption of a genuine peace process" for the creation of a Palestinian state and "halting the colonisation" of the West Bank while visiting Israel on Tuesday, his office says. "The only way to be useful is to one, show solidarity to Israel; two, make commitments against terrorist groups very clear; and three, to open up a political perspective." Macron will also express France's "solidarity" with Israel and the French citizens living there, while also urging "a halt of the colonisation" of the West Bank as a result of Israeli settlements. The French leader's Israel visit for talks with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was announced late on Sunday. Seven French citizens are still missing: one of them, a French woman, has been confirmed as among the hostages taken by Hamas. Macron says the others are also thought to be hostages, but there has not yet been confirmation. AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: French president to discuss creation of Palestinian state on Israel visit

children.content: (File: Reuters)
French President Emmanuel Macron has just touched down in Tel Aviv.

On his visit he will call for the "resumption of a genuine peace process" for the creation of a Palestinian state and "halting the colonisation" of the West Bank while visiting Israel on Tuesday, his office says.
"The only way to be useful is to one, show solidarity to Israel; two, make commitments against terrorist groups very clear; and three, to open up a political perspective."
Macron will also express France's "solidarity" with Israel and the French citizens living there, while also urging "a halt of the colonisation" of the West Bank as a result of Israeli settlements.
The French leader's Israel visit for talks with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was announced late on Sunday.
Seven French citizens are still missing: one of them, a French woman, has been confirmed as among the hostages taken by Hamas.
Macron says the others are also thought to be hostages, but there has not yet been confirmation.
AFP

image.altText: A cartoon image of Jacinta Allan's face.

image.altText: A woman in blue jumper and white scarf crouches down with her black dog with white facial hairs.

image.altText: A photo of a child in school uniform attached to a fridge.

image.altText: a lady wearing a baby blue top sitting in her lounge smiling at the camera.

items.synopsis: The government forecasts it can divert 27,000 people who would otherwise join the National Disability Insurance Scheme into different disability programs. Participants with psychosocial disability say they shouldn't be targeted as a "lesser" group that is not given equal access to the NDIS.
